{"email": [], "image": ["http://thirdlab.cs.vt.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/TatarEdited.jpg", "http://thirdlab.cs.vt.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/DogFacedDeborahEdited.jpg", "http://thirdlab.cs.vt.edu/wp-includes/images/rss.png", "data:image/png;base64,", "data:image/png;base64,", "http://thirdlab.cs.vt.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/TatarGreensAnniversary.jpg", "http://thirdlab.cs.vt.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/BritPic.jpg"], "research_blurb": ["Deborah Tatar is Professor of Computer Science and, by courtesy, Psychology at Virginia Tech, where she is also a member of the Center for Human-Computer Interaction, the Program for Women and Gender Studies,\u00a0 a Fellow of the Institute for Creativity, the Arts and Technology and Fellow of the Institute on Gerontology.\u00a0 She holds a doctorate in Psychology from Stanford and a bachelor\u2019s in English and American Literature and Language from Harvard.\u00a0 She spent sixteen years working in industry and industrial research.Much of her work focuses on the design of multi-user face-to-face systems, especially those designed to fit into and improve classroom interactions.\u00a0\u00a0 This interest dovetails with an interest in the design of technologies as background, the notion of zensign (that what is left out can be as important as what is put into a user interface), phenomena of sharing and human-attention."]}
